articles.headline: An American Household Name in Venezuela
articles.snippet: Buddy Bailey, manager of a Venezuelan baseball team, has become a rarity: an American attaining success and admiration in the land of Hugo Chávez.
articles.abstract: Buddy Bailey, manager of a Venezuelan baseball team, has become a rarity: an American attaining success and admiration in the land of Hugo Chávez.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  Squinting under the Caribbean sun, Buddy Bailey reminisced about a minor-league odyssey that began in the Appalachian League and took him to places like Durham, N.C.; Kingsport, Tenn.; and Pawtucket, R.I.; far from the baseball diamonds of Venezuela.

articles.headline: Emerging Markets Soar Past Their Doubters
articles.snippet: Staggering gains this decade in Brazil, Russia, China, India and other developing nations have left even some bulls wondering if the good times can last.
articles.abstract: Staggering gains this decade in Brazil, Russia, China, India and other developing nations have left even some bulls wondering if the good times can last.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  This was a lost decade for the American stock market. But for much of developing world, it was the Roaring ’00s  a period of soaring markets and breakneck investment that left even some bulls wondering if the good times can last.

articles.headline: F.D.A. to Seek New Standards on Human Test Data
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration will seek tougher standards for data from tests by medical device makers.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration will seek tougher standards for data from tests by medical device makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is developing guidelines that will set tougher scientific standards for data from tests on humans that makers of medical devices submit when seeking approval of their products, a top agency official said.

articles.headline: U.S. Had Early Signals of a Terror Plot, Obama Says
articles.snippet: President Obama said that there had been a “systemic failure” of the security apparatus after he was told of signals that should have prevented the suspect from boarding a plane.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that there had been a “systemic failure” of the security apparatus after he was told of signals that should have prevented the suspect from boarding a plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU  President Obama was told Tuesday about more missed signals and uncorrelated intelligence that should have prevented a would-be bomber from boarding a flight to the United States, leading the president to declare that there had been a “systemic failure” of the nation’s security apparatus.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: China Willing to Spend Big on Afghan Commerce
articles.snippet: A Chinese company is undertaking the largest foreign investment project in war-torn Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A Chinese company is undertaking the largest foreign investment project in war-torn Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Behind an electrified fence, blast-resistant sandbags and 53 National Police outposts, the Afghan surge is well under way.

articles.headline: Health Cuts With Little Effect on Care
articles.snippet: In Richmond, Va., where hospital beds are fewer, health care looks like the rest of the country’s, but cheaper.
articles.abstract: In Richmond, Va., where hospital beds are fewer, health care looks like the rest of the country’s, but cheaper.

articles.headline: Shoplifters? Studies Say Keep an Eye on Workers
articles.snippet: Employee fraud involving gift cards appears to be growing as retailers struggle to contain overall theft.
articles.abstract: Employee fraud involving gift cards appears to be growing as retailers struggle to contain overall theft.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gift cards are just so easy  so easy for dishonest employees to exploit, that is.

articles.headline: Terror Inquiry Looks at Suspect’s Time in Britain
articles.snippet: A look at Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab’s years in London points out a difficulty in preventing terrorist attacks: no one can identify a trigger moment.
articles.abstract: A look at Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab’s years in London points out a difficulty in preventing terrorist attacks: no one can identify a trigger moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by John F. Burns, Landon Thomas Jr. and Ravi Somaiya and written by Mr. Burns.
